title: Omnipresence, multipresence and ubiquity: kinds of generality in and around mathematics and logics
abstract:
A prized property of theories of all kinds is that of generality,\ud
of applicability or least relevance to a wide range of circumstances\ud
and situations. The purpose of this article is to present a pair of distinctions\ud
that suggest that three kinds of generality are to be found in\ud
mathematics and logics, not only at some particular period but especially\ud
in developments that take place over time: ‘omnipresent’ and ‘multipresent’\ud
theories, and ‘ubiquitous’ notions that form dependent parts,\ud
or moments, of theories. The category of ‘facets’ is also introduced,\ud
\ud
primarily to assess the roles of diagrams and notations in these two\ud
disciplines. Various consequences are explored, starting with means of\ud
developing applied mathematics, and then reconsidering several established\ud
ways of elaborating or appraising theories, such as analogising,\ud
revolutions, abstraction, unification, reduction and axiomatisation. The\ud
influence of theories already in place upon theory-building is emphasised.\ud
The roles in both mathematics and logics of set theory, abstract algebras,\ud
metamathematics, and model theory are assessed, along with the different\ud
relationships between the two disciplines adopted in algebraic logic and\ud
in mathematical logic. Finally, the issue of monism versus pluralism in\ud
these two disciplines is rehearsed, and some suggestions are made about\ud
the special character of mathematical and logical knowledge, and also the\ud
differences between them. Since the article is basically an exercise in historiography,\ud
historical examples and case studies are described or noted\ud
throughout
